title: Pass all Shanghai and Cancun tests
Pass all homestead, tangerine, spurious, byzantium and petersburg tests
New config struct design
body:
Config struct now always has the following format:

```
eipXXXX_short_description_name
```

Almost all config options should be boolean flags, but we allow other values as well.

We do this to support both EIP and non-EIP specs -- we may have behaviors that we want to support that is slightly different from the canonical EIP specification, or simply a competing EIP. The new format allows us to properly specify them and support both.

title: Add support both with and without EIP-7610 in jsontests
Initial integration of legacytests
body:
Also added `RuntimeBaseBackend::can_create` to prepare for EIP-7610. Although this is never formally adopted it's apparently already integrated into tests.

However, EIP-7610 is not always possible to implement. For some chains, checking whether storage is empty is too expensive. We therefore provide options to either have EIP-7610, or not have it, via the `can_create` function.

More mainnet convenience functions and some generic refactoring

* Add `evm-mainnet` with some more mainnet convenience functions.

title: Add methods to set/remove delegations to `StackState`
body:
## Description
Adds `set_delegation()` and `remove_delegation()` methods to `StackState` trait for explicit delegation management instead of using generic `set_code()`.

- Adding a `Delegation` struct in a new `core/src/delegation.rs` module
- Introducing `set_delegation()` and `remove_delegation()` methods to `StackState`

title: Change suffix back to -dev after release
Reorganize interpreter crate
body: Flatten it, so that we don't get too much nesting when doing imports.

title: Extensible config
body:
Move config pointer to each frame's state. On the top level, we still need to keep the config pointer in the invoke. This allows two things:

* For a transaction, the config becomes extensible. For example, I can define `EVM64Config`, then create a custom `TransactArgs` and feed it into the standard invoker.
* Account versioning becomes possible. Different call stacks can apply different configs (if ever needed).

title: Async precompile contracts
body:
Users of Rust EVM often implements complex custom precompiles. It is a long requested feature that those precompiles can also do custom call/create just like a normal EVM contract. In the past, this is not easy to do. EVM engines need to use a heap-based call stack (for deep calls), and in this case, a call/create would not continue the function, but must return first. After the call stack finishes executing subcalls, it then "feedbacks" the result to the current level.

This PR implements a way to make it possible. It uses the `async fn` Rust construct that returns a `Future`. Inside the future, we just do a bit of kongfu via `Cell` and `Rc` to capture "action" and receive "feedback". If the action is a call/create, then it traps and the result is later returned via the feedback value. All of those are transparent to the user -- one would only need to write an async function and invoke call/create just like a normal function call.

Apart from a few heap allocations and usage of `Cell`, `Rc`, this method of implementation is performant. However, one needs to make sure that they don't use other async libraries. In general, only `submit.submit` should be `await`ed.

On the call stack level, one needs to implement the trait `standard::Resolver` and customize its `Interpreter` type, usually by creating an enum that choosing from either `EtableInterpreter` and `FutureInterpreter`. It then checks for precompile address and return `FutureInterpreter` for async precompiles.

title: Better EIP-7702 ergonomics
body:
## Description

Using a `Option<H160>` for the authorization address allows to send a `None` value when the signature (`r`, `s`, `y_parity`) is invalid and the authorization needs to be skipped as described in [step 3 of EIP-7702](https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-7702#specification).

body:
## Description

Adds EIP-7702 support.

title: Init evm64 feature
body: `rust-evm` allows customization of literally all aspects of EVM. As a result, new (unstable) features can be added / removed with ease without affecting any other parts of the code. This one initialize the template for `evm64` feature. The actual `eval` and `gasometer` etables are yet to be filled out.

title: Rework multibyte opcode support
body:
* Removed the `Opcode` parameter from `Efn` -- when there are multibyte opcode this becomes confusing, plus the single byte `Opcode` can be easily fetched as `machine.code()[position]`.
* Added `MultiEtable`, where each item can itself be another etable. During evaluation the extra position change will be added by the "parent" node.

title: Polish existing multi-etable and add support for multibyte-etable
body:
At this moment, we're already using multiple etable for best customization support. The current use case is an gasometer etable `eval_gasometer` plus a normal runtime etable. The interpreter would first call the gasometer etable, and upon its success, subsequently invoke the runtime etable.

This PR extends it as follows:

* At this moment, the subsequent invocation happens on `Control::Continue`. This is changed to an explicit `Control::NextTable`.
* A new type `(Etable1, Etable2, [Etable3; N])` is implemented for `EtableSet`. `Etable1` is the gasometer etable. `Etable2` is the normal runtime etable. `[Etable3; N]` is for multi-byte support -- in `Etable2` the eval function can return `Control::NextTable(n)`, and the interpreter would then find the corresponding `n`-th table in the array `[Etable3; N]` and invoke that.

title: Swich interpreter stack from H256 to U256
Add support to DecodeWithMemTracking
body:
# Description 

- Add support to `DecodeWithMemTracking` that is required to upgrade another dependencies that depends on this one to polkadot `stable2503`

Similar to what I did with https://github.com/rust-ethereum/ethereum/pull/62

title: Expose origin and the addresses of contracts being constructed in precompile handle
body:
Exposes the transaction origin in precompile handle, this can be used to identify if an address is an Externally Owner Account (EOA). (`tx.origin == msg.sender`)

This is necessary to distinguish addresses from contracts under-construction and real EOA's, since contracts under-construction only have code after the `init_code` is executed.

Exposing the `origin` to precompiles will be required for supporting https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-7702, since it adds the possibility for EOA to have code.

body:
- [x] Adds 2 new opcodes (`TLOAD` and `TSTORE`) for manipulating state that behaves almost identically to storage but is discarded after every transaction.

    - These new instructions were introduced by [EIP-1153](https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-1153) and included in Cancun fork.

- [x] Adds a new opcode  (`MCOPY`) for copying memory. Implementing this change will be important in ensuring that the same solidity/vyper contract compiles down to the same bytecode.´
   - This new instruction was introduced by [EIP-5656](https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-5656) and included in Cancun fork.

- [x] Changes the behaviour of the self destruct opcode.
   - [EIP-6780: SELFDESTRUCT only in same transaction](https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-6780)

title: Export evm_tracer::standard mod
body: Was it meant to be public? I don't see how else it is useful...

title: Check `exit_substate` result before return
body:
Always verify `exit_result` before updating the state (set_code). @sorpaas 

Note: A patch for the v0.41.1 version.

title: Allow specifying the caller in `set_code` function
body:
### What does it do?

Adds a new `caller` parameter to `set_code` function. This change, allows to manage several behaviors inside each custom implementation of `set_code`, like applying a filter to control which addresses can deploy a contract via inner calls of type `CALL(CREATE)`.

To give more context, in Tanssi and our corresponding forks (of both Frontier and evm), we have implemented such use case. More specifically we have two filters implemented in Frontier:

- `CreateOrigin`: this filter acts when an account is trying to deploy a contract via CREATE method, which is the direct way of creating contracts. In this case, we don't need the caller to be present in `set_code()` as we control the CREATE deployments in `pallet-evm` directly.

- `CreateInnerOrigin`: this filter is applied when an account is trying to deploy a contract via a CALL method, that internally contains a CREATE. In this case, we need the caller to be present in `set_code()`, as this creation will take place inside the substack, and we can't control that behavior from `pallet-evm`.

Also, a good aspect of this change, is that it doesn't break any existing behavior nor compatibility inside the evm.

### Implementation PRs (Tanssi and forks)

**[Tanssi]** Contract deployment customization in frontier template: https://github.com/moondance-labs/tanssi/pull/571
**[Frontier fork]** Customize origin for contract deployment: https://github.com/moondance-labs/frontier/pull/1
**[evm fork]** Modify `set_code` to make it fallible: https://github.com/moondance-labs/evm/pull/1

title: feat: burn base fee when eip-1559 is enabled (>= london fork)
body:
Also adds a new configuration property `eip_1159_enabled` which when set to true, burns the base fee, instead of sending it to the coinbase address.

> An important aspect of this fee system is that miners only get to keep the priority fee. The base fee is always burned (i.e. it is destroyed by the protocol). This ensures that only ETH can ever be used to pay for transactions on Ethereum, cementing the economic value of ETH within the Ethereum platform and reducing risks associated with miner extractable value (MEV). Additionally, this burn counterbalances Ethereum inflation while still giving the block reward and priority fee to miners. Finally, ensuring the miner of a block does not receive the base fee is important because it removes miner incentive to manipulate the fee in order to extract more fees from users.

body: Something I missed in PR #282

title: Use macros to reduce boilerplate code
Cancun self destruct changes (EIP 6780)
body:
This PR implements the new changes for the `selfdestruct` function as outlined in [EIP-6780](https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-6780). 

The new EIP allows for contract deletion only within the same transaction that created it. Otherwise, the `selfdestruct` function will simply transfer all Ether in the contract account to the target address.

Another change introduced by this EIP is that when `selfdestruct` is not called in the same transaction that created the contract, if the target address is the same as the contract address, there is no net change in balances. Unlike the previous specification, Ether will not be burned in this case.

title: Fix eip2929 implementation
body: Includes a fix related to [EIP-2929](https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-2929), where some addresses were incorrectly considered `cold` and consumed extra gas. I identified this issue when running the tests located at [`ethtests/GeneralStateTests/Cancun/stEIP1153-transientStorage`](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/Cancun/stEIP1153-transientStorage), which were failing because the gas costs did not match.

title: feat: support memory copying instruction (EIP-5656)
body:
This PR adds an adaptation to [EIP-5656](https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-5656) which introduces the `MCOPY` opcode. 

By using this new instruction, it is possible to copy parts of the memory in a cheaper and easier way, everything done with one opcode.

### Note

All the Cancun [ethereum-tests](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/428f218d7d6f4a52544e12684afbfe6e2882ffbf/GeneralStateTests/Cancun/stEIP5656-MCOPY) related to `MCOPY` pass with this implementation.

title: feat: support transient storage opcodes (EIP-1153)
body:
This PR adds 2 new opcodes (`TLOAD` and `TSTORE`) for manipulating state that behaves almost identically to storage but is discarded after every transaction. 

These new instructions were introduced by [EIP-1153](https://eips.ethereum.org/EIPS/eip-1153) and included in Cancun fork.

Running the tests located at [`ethtests/GeneralStateTests/Cancun/stEIP1153-transientStorage`](https://github.com/ethereum/tests/tree/develop/src/GeneralStateTestsFiller/Cancun/stEIP1153-transientStorage) will require the changes present in https://github.com/rust-ethereum/evm/pull/280

title: Properly return retval in TransactValue
body: For a CALL transaction, we should return the `retval`, because some RPC calls need it.

body: An overlayed backend, provide `TransactionalBackend` and `RuntimeBackend` implementation for anything that implements `RuntimeBaseBackend`.

title: Chore: silence clippy closure in match warning
Fix cleanup_create order and release v0.41.1
Feat: extend Invoker visibility
body:
## Description

Currently `evm::transact` accepts any kind `Invoker`, as a most flexible solution:

```
pub fn transact<H, Tr, I>(
	args: I::TransactArgs,
	heap_depth: Option<usize>,
	backend: &mut H,
	invoker: &I,
) -> Result<I::TransactValue, ExitError>
where
	I: Invoker<H, Tr, Interrupt = Infallible>,
	I::Interpreter: RunInterpreter<H, Tr>,
```

➡️ This PR solves the visibility issue for types and dependencies to implement custom `Invoker`.

title: Chore: Refactoring with simplification and more idiomatic clippy-way
body:
## Description

🔦  Refactored and simplified some parts of the code. And for some parts of the code applied more strict rules through clippy: `pedantic` and `nursery`. It's only partly compatible with that, as some part of the code, AFAIK represented for better readability. PR changes do not touch parts related to a better visual understanding of the code.

➡️  Additional notes about adding `map_err`: as it's more idiomatic way to process error flow for factored parts of code.

title: Feat: add rust tests for jsontests
body:
## Description

Currently, tests are represented via `jsontests` crate. It's a good tool 💯, to use as a CLI standalone application.

➡️ This PR also added possibilities to use `Rust` specific way to run tests with: `cargo test`.

➡️ The main motivation is to run tests through `Rust`, to choose which tests to run, and to be able to add tests later. And mostly go through cargo test flow. However, this does not negate all the capabilities of the CLI application. For this purpose, refactoring was done, and utility functions were placed in a separate module, which will allow them to be used both in the application and in `Rust` tests.

➡️ Also added comments to the code where it makes sense.

➡️ Each single test runs tests from a separate `evm jsontests` directory.

➡️ The CI has been refactored (however, in this particular case - I'm not sure what is more representative from the CI point of view - running as an application or as `cargo test`).

title: Feat: Add statistics info for jsontests
body:
## Description

➡️ At the moment, when tests are run, the output results are uninformative and difficult to analyze. This PR adds minimal statistical information to the tests passed and changes the output to make it more convenient to analyze.

### 🌇 Changes

- [x] Added `TestCompletionStatus` type
- [x] For test-run functions added completion status result
- [x] Added statistic info function for:
   - [x] File test
   - [x] Directory test
  -  [x] Total tests pass
- [x] Changed output for tests with format: 

```
[FORK_NAME] SHORT_TEST_FILE_NAME | TEST_NAME/INDEX: COMPLETION_STATUS
```  

#### ✅ Example output for a single test
```
[Berlin] VMTests/vmTests/calldataload.json | calldataload/2: ok
[Cancun] VMTests/vmTests/calldataload.json | calldataload/0: skipped
```

#### ✅ Example statistic info output 

```
COMPLETED: 3 tests
SKIPPED: 15 tests

TOTAL tests for: jsontests/res/ethtests/GeneralStateTests/VMTests/vmTests/
	COMPLETED: 136
	SKIPPED: 680

TOTAL: 5240 tests
	COMPLETED: 772
	SKIPPED: 4468
```

title: Remove unnecessary S generic in EtableInterpreter and EtableResolver
Several refactor work (attempt 2)
body:
A different version of #253 where we only move `State` into associate type. In certain cases, it's still possible to implement `Interpreter` over an generic `Handle` -- switching handle type in the middle of an execution.

If you are not convinced, this version removed several `PhantomData` that was previously there.

title: Better trap handling
body:
Introduce two different traits `TrapConsume` and `TrapConstruct`.

`TrapConstruct` is self-explanatory -- given a base-type trap, it warps it to the top-level enum.

`TrapConsume` should be implemented on the top-level enum for all possibilities of trap handling orders, and reduce the type into `Rest`. For example, if a VM has three different types of traps -- `CallCreateTrap`, `dyn Future<Output = Control<Tr>>` for storage access, and `Interrupt`. Then `TrapConsume<CallCreateTrap>` should return an enum containing two other variants `dyn Future<Output = Control<Tr>>` and `Interrupt`, and so forth.

title: refactor: introduce Interpreter trait and merge RuntimeState/GasometerState
body:
In Rust, the current best method of doing interpretation is not available -- to implement things like direct threading (to avoid extra jumps), we'll need either goto, or guaranteed tail optimization. It's therefore best if we make the actual execution code generic so that people can use what's best on their targets (for example, tail optimization works on x86 but not really on wasm). Eventually, we'd also want to have at least two different modes -- a baseline, and an analyzed, where the former try to use as little memory as possible, and the latter are allowed to use more, optimizing for speed.

When handling substate merging, we currently differentiate runtime vs. gasometer, which is unnecessary. So we merge them together -- gasometer is just a state in the machine's runtime.
